disconfirming_evidence_not_found.hypothesis: H1: Critical operations rely on undocumented human knowledge
disconfirming_evidence_not_found.evidence_sought_but_not_found: Comprehensive knowledge management infrastructure including: (1) Platform architecture documentation enabling new staff to maintain systems without tribal knowledge, (2) Operational runbooks with troubleshooting procedures for common/rare failures, (3) Knowledge management system (wiki, confluence, internal documentation portal) with active maintenance, (4) Cross-training programs rotating staff through critical roles, (5) Documented succession plans showing backup personnel for each key role, (6) Evidence of successful knowledge transfers when key personnel departed (smooth transitions, no operational disruption).
disconfirming_evidence_not_found.why_absence_matters: Absence confirms knowledge IS concentrated and undocumented as suspected. If comprehensive documentation existed, Rackspace would BENEFIT from disclosing it: (1) Recruitment advantage ('join us, we have great documentation and onboarding'), (2) Investor confidence ('operations not dependent on specific individuals'), (3) Operational resilience ('can handle personnel turnover'), (4) Valuation support ('systematic not heroic operations'). Absence suggests: Either (1) Documentation doesn't exist (knowledge truly concentrated), or (2) Documentation exists but inadequate (not comprehensive enough to matter), or (3) Documentation exists but unmaintained (stale, unreliable). All three interpretations concerning. Combined with explicit Stage 6.3 statement 'platforms contain UNDOCUMENTED LOGIC' and Stage 4.5 'legacy system custodians possess UNDOCUMENTED operational knowledge', absence of documentation evidence VALIDATES hypothesis rather than weakens it.
next_best_sources_to_check: Employee onboarding materials for technical roles (how quickly can new staff become productive?)
Platform vendor contracts showing extent of vendor vs internal knowledge required
Post-incident reviews citing lack of documentation as contributing factor
Employee exit interviews mentioning difficulty transferring knowledge
Confluence/Wiki activity logs showing documentation creation/maintenance patterns

disconfirming_evidence_not_found.hypothesis: H2: Key-person dependencies exist despite organizational scale
disconfirming_evidence_not_found.evidence_sought_but_not_found: Evidence of redundancy and distributed authority including: (1) Operating committee or governance board distributing CEO coordination load, (2) Multiple staff authorized and capable of approving major deals (not requiring CEO), (3) Backup platform architects documented and trained for each critical platform, (4) Business continuity plans explicitly naming backup personnel for each key role, (5) Evidence of smooth operations during extended key personnel absences (CEO vacation, architect illness), (6) Rapid backfill case studies showing departed key person replaced within 30-90 days without disruption.
disconfirming_evidence_not_found.why_absence_matters: Absence confirms single points of failure ARE structural not fixable by better staffing. If redundancy existed, Rackspace would BENEFIT from evidencing it: (1) Risk mitigation for investors ('no key-person risk'), (2) Customer confidence ('service continuity guaranteed'), (3) Operational resilience messaging ('deep bench strength'), (4) Lower insurance premiums (key-person insurance less necessary). Absence suggests: Redundancy DOESN'T EXIST despite organizational scale (~7,000 employees inferred from $709M SG&A). Three CEOs three years PROVES CEO role lacks succession plan - each transition improvised. Stage 4.1 explicitly states 'NO OPERATING COMMITTEE' - proves authority not distributed. Stage 6.3 platform analysis infers single architects per platform. Absence of redundancy evidence STRUCTURAL - organization designed to centralize creating fragility.
next_best_sources_to_check: Organizational charts with backup roles identified
Key person insurance policies (reveals who company views as irreplaceable)
Board meeting minutes discussing succession planning
CEO employment agreement with transition/succession provisions
Platform architect job descriptions showing team size (1 vs 2+ per platform)

disconfirming_evidence_not_found.hypothesis: H3: Attrition risk compounds during stress - post-crisis departures reduce capacity for next crisis
disconfirming_evidence_not_found.evidence_sought_but_not_found: Evidence of retention stability and sustainable operations including: (1) Turnover data showing NO INCREASE following major incidents (Exchange, ScienceLogic, CL0P), (2) Employee retention programs specifically for high-stress roles (retention bonuses, sabbaticals, workload relief), (3) Automated incident response systems reducing personnel burden over time, (4) Employee testimonials about sustainable workload and work-life balance, (5) Post-incident debriefs identifying personnel stress and implementing mitigation, (6) Glassdoor/employee reviews praising incident response culture and support.
disconfirming_evidence_not_found.why_absence_matters: Absence confirms burnout → attrition → reduced capacity death spiral IS occurring. If retention were stable post-incident, Rackspace would SHOWCASE it: (1) Employer branding ('we support our people through crises'), (2) Customer confidence ('stable team delivers consistent service'), (3) Talent recruitment ('join a resilient, well-supported team'). Absence after three incidents in 36 months particularly concerning - suggests either (1) Retention IS problem but undisclosed, or (2) Retention not tracked/measured (worse - unaware of problem). Stage 4.5 explicitly rates burnout risk HIGH to EXTREME across five organizational zones. Three CEOs three years demonstrates LEADERSHIP attrition. Trustpilot 'worse' 2024 suggests OPERATIONS attrition creating customer-visible degradation. Exchange service DISCONTINUATION may reflect insufficient personnel post-ransomware. Absence of retention evidence VALIDATES compounding attrition hypothesis.
next_best_sources_to_check: HR turnover data by role and timing relative to incidents
Employee engagement survey results (burnout metrics, satisfaction trends)
Retention bonus program documentation (if exists, who receives, amounts)
Glassdoor reviews filtered by date (do negative reviews spike post-incident?)
Exit interview data (why do people leave? burnout mentioned?)
Headcount trends over time (declining headcount suggests attrition exceeds hiring)
